column4: which application is responsible for automounting my phone's memory card when I plug it in to a USB port please?
probably the same one responsible automounting other kind of cards and other storage devices
are you plugging it in and finding it doesn't automount and trying to figure out why?
yes.  until today it was automounting.  now it isn't.  I'm wondering how I broke it.
does it show up in "dmesg" command output?

these are the things I disabled earlier today, thinking them unneccesary for me: bluetooth manager, evolution alarm notifier, gnome login sound, network manager, print queue applet, pulseaudio session manager, remote desktop, user folders update, and visual assistance
also, does it add a device to the contents of /proc/partitions ?
try re-enabling user folders update
it shows up as '[25301.220307] usb 1-6.3: new full speed USB device using ehci_hcd and address 37'
OK, so the driver sees it ... the kernel does not automount it ... some user program gets notified of new device and does so ... that may be connected to the folders update
it doesn't add anything to /proc/partitions
try re-enabling user folders update
and reboot to be sure things got started that might not be
I have done.  I've not rebooted or logged out and in again since, but I also didn't do either since disabling it...
I think 'user folders update' is responsible for recreating a bunch of empty folders every time I log in: ~/Porn, ~/TV and such like - that I then have to delete
something adds a new folder for a drive when I plug in a drive ... was just a guess
I also took the liberty of uninstalling pulseaudio or some such.  it was taking a lot of RAM, and making audio and video be out of sync
I have no idea with all these apps and things ... I'm more of a kernel, driver, bootloader, firmware, embedded stuff programmer
but I would have thought that would be related to this problem - just trying to think what I've changed today
I doubt pulseaudio is responsible
the sync problems are inherit in bad format designs for most of the audio-video formats ... players have to do weird things to keep them in sync ... some do better than others
ok, fine :)
it seems that disabling startup apps and removing pulseaudio had no effect.
I switched to a different USB port and now automount is working again
